fields.headline: 82. Bob Phillis
fields.bodyText: Job: chief executive, Guardian Media Group Age: 58 Industry: publishing, broadcasting, new media Company turnover: £526m Staff: 3,170 Salary: £360,000 2003 ranking: 92 As chief executive of the Guardian Media Group, Bob Phillis oversees a company spanning national and regional newspapers, magazines, radio and the internet. A former deputy director general of the BBC, Sir Robert chaired the independent review that this year ushered in sweeping changes to the government's communications machine. White House-style televised briefings of political reporters were among the recommendations of the Phillis review, which identified a "culture of secrecy and partial disclosure of information" in Whitehall. Sir Robert, who was knighted this year for services to the media industry, previously spearheaded an investigation into TV production that backed more rights for independent producers. "He has a whole range of broadcast and newspaper experience, and is one of those people that keeps cropping up heading independent reviews and inquiries," said one member of the panel. GMG paid £593m to take full control of Auto Trader parent Trader Media Group last year. It has also extended its portfolio with the £2m acquisition of a 27% stake in Seven, the publisher behind celebrity food title Delicious. Sir Robert took over the reins as GMG chief executive in 1997. Along with the Guardian and Observer newspapers, it owns three radio franchises in Jazz FM, Smooth FM and Real Radio, and more than 40 regional newspapers including the Manchester Evening News). Its award-winning internet operation includes the Guardian Unlimited network of sites, workthing.com and learn.co.uk. The Guardian Media Group chief is also chairman of All3Media, the independent production company behind Richard and Judy and Midsomer Murders.
